page.title: Who Cares About Assessments and Why?
page.contents:
Stakeholders and Assessment

So far, we’ve briefly explored diagnostic, formative and summative assessment. Now let’s consider who these assessments might be important to, and what the assessment results might be used for.  Please read the article excerpt below.  This section of the resource focuses on the idea that no single assessment can serve every need, and that assessments are developed or selected based on the interests of each stakeholder.

Thoughts on an Assessment of Common Core Standards  (pdf format)

(excerpt only - Introduction – pages 3-4)
By Stephen Lazer, John Mazzeo, Jon S. Twing, Walter D. Way, Wayne J. Camara, and Kevin Sweeney; Educational Testing Service (ETS), Pearson, and College Board (joint publishers – no date).

Questions for Discussion:

Consider the following questions for discussion with your peers:

  • Who are the people who have a vested interest in your program (the stakeholders)? 
  • What type of information do they request and how do you collect this information for them? 
  • Do you find that collecting program information is helpful for yourself and your students? If so, how?  If not, why not?
